author: Saijel Kishan
title: Winton Fund Slips 3.1% in June, Hurt by Decline in Europe Stocks
text:
Winton Capital Management, David Harding’s $32 billion hedge fund firm, lost about 3.1 percent in June as European stocks posted their biggest monthly drop in two years.
The fall brings the $12.1 billion Winton Futures Fund’s decline for the year to 1.9 percent, according to a letter sent to investors, a copy of which was obtained by Bloomberg News. The firm uses computer algorithms to determine how it trades.
Tumbling stock markets in June have curtailed the best start to a year for hedge funds since the financial crisis of 2008. In Europe, the STOXX Europe 50 index fell 4.6 percent in the month amid uncertainty about whether Greece will remain in the euro. Chinese equities slumped on concern valuations have reached unsustainable levels.
In addition to European stocks, Winton said it lost money on its bets against the euro and corn. Alexandra Rhys-Jones, a spokeswoman for the London-based firm, didn’t immediately respond to an e-mail and telephone message seeking comment.
